column2: P5JS - Customizing your art (The sky's the limit!)
What you'll do
Learn how to make other shapes, etc. and unlock the full potential of P5JS (Part 4)
You're back! You must love programming as much as I do! Let's start by opening the editor: https://editor.p5js.org (if you don't already have it open).

It might seem like I know everything there is to know about *p5.js*, but I'll that's only because I started learning it a couple weeks before you did. There's still a lot I don't know, and I want to explore it with you. Problems can be a lot easier with a partner!
Let me show you the *p5.js* version of the Academy Archives - it's where I learned everything I know about it.
If you look up at the menus at the top, you'll see a menu called *Help*.
Click on it, and you'll see an option called *Reference*. That's where we want to go.
I know the Reference can be overwhelming at first - there's a *huge* amount of information here. Let's look up something we already know about - the `background()` command.
If you can't find it, use *Ctrl+F* to search on the page. That's how I usually find what I'm looking for on reference pages. Once you find it, click the link to take us in.
OK, now we're on the `background()` reference page. At the top, you'll see lots of different examples of how to use this bit of code.
The first example just has a number in the parentheses - that's what we started off with in the very first quest, remember? I always wondered what it meant...
Oh, I see - it's a *grayscale* number, a value between 0 and 255 that tells you how dark or light the gray should be.
If you look down a few entries, you'll see `background('red');` - that's how we set the color the first time.
A little ways down, there's `background('#222222');` - there's the hex color format we used later!
Wow, there's so many different ways to set the background color! Scrolling down even further, you can read about how it works.
Let's go back and check out another entry. Click the back button, then find `circle()` on the page.
This one's a lot simpler, there's only one example and it looks just like what we used!
If you scroll down to the *Syntax* section, you'll see how to use it: with three different numbers that represent the x, y, and diameter.
Here in the reference, they use the placeholders *x*, *y*, and *d* for those numbers, and they explain what each one means in the section below.
The section below is called *Parameters*, and that's what you call each of the things inside the parentheses of a function like *circle()*.
So the *parameters* of the *circle()* function are the X-coordinate, the Y-coordinate, and the diameter.
Okay, now that we know how to read these reference entries, let's go find a new function to look up, like *square()*.
See if you can use the reference for *square()* to draw your own square in the editor!
I did `square(mouseX, mouseY, 50);` to get a square with 50-pixel sides that follows my mouse around - That's a cool new paintbrush!
There are also two other parts of this site that have been super useful to me - If you look on the left side of the reference page, you'll see *Learn* and *Examples*.
Click around each of those sections to find out more about the possibilities of *p5.js*!
That's all for now - I can't wait to see what amazing things you'll create! Isn't programming cool?
